awd_titl_txt: Molecular Mechanisms of Protein Association with Plastoglobule Lipid Droplets
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will explore the mechanisms of protein association with plastoglobules, lipid droplets that exist in the photosynthetic compartment of plant cells. Accumulated evidence indicates that plastoglobules are highly important for effective plant tolerance to a range of environmental stresses. However, it remains unclear what role they play in the cell to facilitate stress tolerance within plants. This research will unravel the relationship between plastoglobule function and stress tolerance by uncovering principles governing the establishment and dynamic regulation of the plastoglobule protein set. Results from this research may provide a foundation for development of agricultural and horticultural crops that are more nutritious and more resilient to environmental challenges. This project will provide scientific training to researchers of diverse backgrounds and career stages. Lesson materials and in-class demonstrations for elementary school students will be developed based on concepts and results of the project that will serve thousands of children from highly diverse socioeconomic and ethnic groups. These lessons will educate students about the value of plants as a source of food, the challenges plants face in nature, and the role of plant science in overcoming these challenges.

Dozens of structural and enzymatic proteins associate peripherally at the surface of plastoglobule lipid droplets of chloroplasts. Most of these plastoglobule-associated proteins are known to specifically associate to the plastoglobule, although the molecular mechanisms which underlie this remarkable specificity are unknown. This project will employ integrated biochemical and microscopic techniques to uncover mechanistic principles governing the specific association of proteins. Sequence regions necessary for plastoglobule association will be identified by testing fluorescent localization of truncated and site-directed mutagenized proteins. Lipid-binding capabilities of proteins and relevant sequence regions will be investigated using lipid overlay and vesicle-binding experiments. To determine the impact of post-translational modifications on plastoglobule association, coupled top-down and bottom-up proteomics will be conducted on isolated chloroplast sub-compartments. The research will develop understanding of protein-membrane interactions at a mechanistic level, with implications for all domains of life, particularly other curved or monolayer membranes such as cytoplasmic lipid droplets, micelles, or lipoprotein particles.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We have investigated how specific proteins are able to localize to the surface of plastoglobule lipid droplets of plant chloroplasts. We have successfully identified a major determinant of plastoglobule protein targeting: the presence of an amphipathic helix lacking large hydrophobic residues and flanked by multiple negatively charged residues. Deletion of the amphipathic helix from two plastoglobule-localized Fibrillin proteins eliminated their plastoglobule association, as evidenced by confocal microscopy and biochemical fractionation. Molecular dynamics simulations and biophysical experimentation (pendant-drop tensiometry) corroborated the significance of the amphipathic helices in plastoglobule interaction. In addition, we have delineated the lipid-binding characteristics of these same two Fibrillin proteins. We demonstrate unique binding preferences among the two Fibrillin proteins and distinct effects of lipid binding in the absence of their amphipathic helices.

We do not suggest that the lipid binding abilities of these Fibrillins are responsible for their plastoglobule-localization. Rather, we propose a model by which Fibrillins bind specific lipids and transport them between differing chloroplast membranes and utilize distinct sequence motifs for association to each membrane, as appropriate to the properties of each membrane surface; with the amphipathic helix being the key motif used for interaction with the plastoglobule.

Our results represent the first identification of a plastoglobule-targeting strategy, an important benchmark in the study of the plastoglobule. This opens the door to a detailed exploration of the molecular mechanisms underlying plastoglobule-protein association, will permit more accurate searches for candidate plastoglobule proteins, and will facilitate the development of the plastoglobule as a platform for metabolic engineering.

We have also developed a pair of outreach materials that bring plant science topics into the homes and schools of pre-teen children:

1. A 'Science Roadshow', a hands-on science demonstration/lesson on scientific separation methods, e.g. centrifugation and gel electrophoresis. This lesson brings lab equipment and prepared hands-on activities to middle and high school students throughout central Michigan as part of the 4-H Children’s Garden science outreach program. The activities have been very well received and will serve as an on-going outreach activity for many years to come.

2. A video tour of our biochemistry laboratory space to bring the students “into” a functioning laboratory and introduce them to the equipment that is used. The 10-minute video includes demonstrations and discussions of nine different common lab activities including bacterial incubation, centrifugation and buffer preparation, and is posted publicly on YouTube through MSU’s 4-H Children’s Garden channel.
